AIA Articles.Article_Name: Northrop upgrades B-2's data transfer capabilities
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: The US Air Force and Northrop Grumman have successfully tested new digital data transmission capabilities for the B-2 bomber. This demonstration, part of the B-2 Collaborative Combat Communication program, involved data transfer between a B-2 Adaptable Communications Suite ground station and a B-2 Spirit aircraft equipped with Northrop Grumman's Multi Mission Domain architecture.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Contractor-owned drones reduce risk for Navy
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: The US Navy has expanded its fleet of ships utilizing unmanned aircraft systems through contractor-owned/contractor-operated models, with Textron Systems confirming the award of a contract for UAS operational support on two Independence-class and one Freedom-class littoral combat ships. "The contractor-owned/contactor-operated model provides a lower-risk option for the navy to support their growing surface fleet and rapidly introduce additional unmanned capabilities," said Wayne Prender, senior vice-president of Textron Systems Air Systems.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Air Force lab pursues quantum computing breakthrough
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: The US Air Force Research Lab has inaugurated a new Extreme Computing Facility in Rome, N.Y., aimed at advancing the US military's quantum computing capabilities. The facility includes laboratories for quantum computing, networking, security, and neuromorphic computing, marking a significant step in the international competition for quantum technology and the race with China.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Boeing provides $500K for Maui wildfire relief
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Boeing has given $500,000 to support wildfire relief efforts in Maui, Hawaii, following an outbreak of deadly wildfires on the island. The donation, divided equally between the American Red Cross and Hawai'i Community Foundation's Maui Strong Fund, is part of Boeing's ongoing commitment to disaster recovery and humanitarian efforts, with Hawaiian Airlines, American Airlines, and Delta Air Lines and others also contributing through various means.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: FAA approves Archer's eVTOL flights amid investments
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Archer Aviation, in its second-quarter financial report, says it has received FAA approval to begin flight tests on its Midnight electric vertical take-off and landing aircraft. A new round of investments from Stellantis and United Airlines are also boosting Archer's outlook.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: DHL signs on as Eve Air logistics support provider
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Eve Air Mobility has entered into a partnership with DHL Supply Chain to enhance its supply chain services. The collaboration will focus on designing a concept for "eVTOL support" services, including the delivery of batteries, spare parts, and supplies, leveraging DHL's extensive warehousing and distribution expertise to support Eve's future operations.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: IndiGo favors Dreamliner for 25-plane order, sources say
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: Boeing appears to be leading the race to secure an order for approximately 25 wide-body aircraft from IndiGo, India's largest airline, as part of its international expansion efforts. While IndiGo is considering Boeing's 787 family of twin-aisle planes, competing against Airbus A330neo jets, the final decision has not yet been made.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: Senate confirmation pause leaves service branches in lurch
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: For the first time in history, three military services are without Senate-confirmed leaders, due to Sen. Tommy Tuberville, R-Ala., holding up over 300 senior military officer confirmations in protest of the Pentagon's new abortion policy. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin criticized the holds as "unprecedented, unnecessary, and unsafe.

AIA Articles.Article_Name: DSCA offers new repay option for FMS deals
AIA Articles.Article_Summary: The Defense Security Cooperation Agency has announced a new Bank Letter of Credit policy as a way to make payments on foreign military sales agreements or supplement funds on existing offers. The new policy applies to US banks with an "A" rating or higher.
